title: CArCRT Formally Known as CADaCT-SL engages in mass campaign against drug abuse in Kenema
excerpt: Coalition Against Drugs Abuse and Community Transformation (CArCRT-SL). The Cross of Christ Association (CCA), in collaboration with the Widow Empowerment Organization and Partners, on Saturday 15th November 2025, took part in a day-long mass sensitization rally against all forms of drug abuse.
content:
Thousands of residents from various organisations and institutions joined the rally by assembling at the Sierra Leone Police barracks field along Hangha Road, using a public address system and other instruments mounted on a canopy, singing, dancing and preaching messages of drug abuse as they proceeded through Hangha Road, Dama Road, Kingsway Street, Combema Road, Sumaila Street, Koroma Street and Hangha Road to the police barracks, where various stakeholders addressed the gathering in connection to drug abuse.

The Chief Executive Officer of CADaCT-SL, Saffa Andrew Koroma, while addressing his audience, thanks all and sundry for taking part in the rally, adding the musical performance, drama, poetry, comedy, spiritual counselling, statements and pledges by dignitaries are moves in the right direction in eradicating drug abuse from our society.
Saffa Andrew Koroma, CADaCT-SL CEO, gave thanks to all partners for their diverse support; among them are Trading Organic, Sierra Leone Red Cross, Sierra Leone Police, Republic of Sierra Leone Armed Forces, Eastern Technical University Sierra Leone, 42 secondary schools, Inter Religious Council and other community stakeholders, DHMT, Mr Jimmy Batilo Songa, Radish Bar and Restaurant, Ministry of Gender and Children Affairs, Resident Minister East, Human Rights Commission, Scrap Metals Association, Africel Sierra Leone, Orange Sierra Leone, Mayor of Kenema City Council, Paramount Chiefs, AIG East, BRU, Drivers Union, KDFA and the media outlets (print, electronic and bloggers).

He pointed out that the objective of the entire rally is to raise public awareness on the dangers of drug abuse through culturally resonant messaging.

Mobilise corporate, non governmental, and civil society actors to co-invest in prevention and rehabilitation.

Equip youth and community leaders with knowledge and tools to resist peer pressure and substance misuse. Strengthen referral pathways for treatment, psychosocial support, and reintegration.

title: School Sponsorship Program Field Visit – KmDEC Primary School
excerpt: As part of the ongoing School Sponsorship Program led by the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT) — formerly known as CADACT-SL — the team conducted a monitoring and validation visit on 24th November 2025
content:
School Sponsorship Program Field Visit – KmDEC Primary School

As part of the ongoing School Sponsorship Program led by the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT) — formerly known as CADACT-SL — the team conducted a monitoring and validation visit on 24th November 2025.

A delegation headed by CEO Saffa Andrew Koroma, together with CArCRT staff and interns, visited KmDEC Primary School, one of ten supported schools located on Moiwo Street, Kenema. The visit aimed to verify the accuracy of recent child-sponsorship assessments and address concerns about increased vulnerability among learners.

The engagement was successful, and all issues raised by the school administration were addressed collaboratively.

Key Action Points Identified

Training for Guidance Counselors to strengthen psychosocial support.

Teacher capacity-building on child protection policies and safeguarding laws.

Regular engagement with parents and caregivers to improve support for vulnerable children.

Provision of essential learning materials for identified beneficiaries.

CArCRT remains committed to supporting vulnerable children through inclusive education, strengthened school systems, and community involvement.

title: CArCRT Partners with Sierra Leone Correctional Service to Launch “Project Closed Setting”
excerpt: As part of our ongoing commitment to community resilience, psychosocial support, and dignity restoration, the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT) has initiated a strategic collaboration with the Sierra Leone Correctional Service, Kenema. This partnership aims to strengthen rehabilitation pathways and improve support systems for inmates through our new initiative titled Project Closed Setting.
content:
CArCRT Partners with Sierra Leone Correctional Service to Launch “Project Closed Setting”

As part of our ongoing commitment to community resilience, psychosocial support, and dignity restoration, the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT) has initiated a strategic collaboration with the Sierra Leone Correctional Service, Kenema. This partnership aims to strengthen rehabilitation pathways and improve support systems for inmates through our new initiative titled Project Closed Setting.

About the Project

Project Closed Setting focuses on providing holistic rehabilitation and reintegration support for inmates through:

1. Psychosocial Support & Counseling

Individual and group counseling sessions

Trauma healing and emotional recovery

Mentorship programs to rebuild confidence, resilience, and hope

2. Skills Training & Entrepreneurship

Practical vocational training

Entrepreneurship and business development skills

Opportunities to prepare inmates for sustainable livelihoods post-release

3. Dignity Support for Women

Tailored programs for female inmates

Hygiene and dignity kits

Empowerment sessions aimed at reducing stigma and restoring self-worth

4. Reintegration & Safe Life After Prison

Structured reintegration planning

Community mentorship and referral pathways

Agribusiness and livelihood opportunities to support a smooth transition back into society

Our Commitment

Through this partnership, CArCRT continues to champion inclusive rehabilitation, promote human dignity, and support second chances for individuals in closed settings. We believe that every person—regardless of circumstance—deserves access to healing, growth, and the opportunity to rebuild their lives.

title: CArCRT (formerly CADacT) Joins the Ministry of Social Welfare on Visit to Daru Drug Rehabilitation Facility
excerpt:
On 18th November 2025, the Ministry of Social Welfare, in collaboration with the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT), formerly known as CADacT, conducted an official visit to the Government’s Harmful Drug Rehabilitation Facility in Daru, Jawei Chiefdom, Kailahun District.

The visit aimed to assess ongoing rehabilitation efforts, encourage recovering victims, and reaffirm national commitment toward ending the harmful drug crisis affecting Sierra Leone’s youth.
content:
CArCRT (formerly CADacT) Joins the Ministry of Social Welfare on Visit to Daru Drug Rehabilitation Facility

On 18th November 2025, the Ministry of Social Welfare, in collaboration with the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT), formerly known as CADacT, conducted an official visit to the Government’s Harmful Drug Rehabilitation Facility in Daru, Jawei Chiefdom, Kailahun District.

The visit aimed to assess ongoing rehabilitation efforts, encourage recovering victims, and reaffirm national commitment toward ending the harmful drug crisis affecting Sierra Leone’s youth.

Government’s Commitment to Rehabilitation

During the visit, Mr. Darlington Kajua Sesay, Director of Social Welfare (East), highlighted the Government’s multi-pronged approach to rehabilitation.
He noted that functional facilities are already established in:

Hastings (Freetown)

Gondama (Bo)

Daru (Kailahun)

Plans are underway to establish an additional centre in Teko (Makeni).
He emphasized the crucial support of the military in helping rebuild the future of Sierra Leone through structured rehabilitation.

CArCRT’s Stand Against Drug Abuse

Andrew Saffa Koroma, CEO of CArCRT (formerly CADacT), expressed deep concern about the alarming rise of Kush and other synthetic drugs, calling the situation a national crisis that threatens the country’s future.

He commended Minister Melrose Karminty, Minister of Social Welfare, for her unwavering support and leadership in the national fight against drugs.

Saffa reaffirmed CArCRT’s determination to contribute through:

Prevention programs

Rehabilitation support

Justice and community accountability

He concluded by calling on all Sierra Leoneans to unite and save the nation’s youth from the destructive grip of harmful drugs.

Voices of Concern and Compassion

Madam Nancy Admire Mustapha, Executive Director of Widows Empowerment, grew visibly emotional as testimonials were shared—especially the story of Jimmy Jajua, one of the recovering victims.

She reminded the youths:

“If you destroy your future now, no one will be left to develop Sierra Leone. We see potential in all of you, and that is why we are here.”

Representing the Sierra Leone Police, Sub-Inspector Brima James Musa, Head of Media (East), strongly condemned those producing and selling Kush—including parents who profit from the trade—describing it as a betrayal of parental duty.

Centre Updates

Pastor Solomon Kamara, Acting Centre Coordinator, expressed gratitude to President Bio for his timely leadership in addressing the drug crisis.

Providing statistics, Elizabeth Katay Toogbabu, Social Worker (Kenema Regional Office), reported that the centre currently hosts:

39 service users

34 males

5 females

The facility is structured into two sections (male and female), with separate billets:

3 billets for males

1 billet for females

Conclusion

The visit ended with group photos, engagement sessions, and psychosocial counselling for the recovering clients.

CArCRT remains committed to supporting the Government and communities in building resilience, restoring dignity, and protecting Sierra Leone’s youth.

title: CArCRT (formerly CADacT) and Partners Engage the Public Ahead of November 15th Drugs Campaign in Kenema
excerpt:
CArCRT (formerly CADacT) and Partners Engage the Public Ahead of November 15th Drugs Campaign in Kenema

Ahead of the November 15th Drugs Campaign in Kenema, the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT), formerly CADacT, and its partners appeared on a simulcast radio discussion to speak on their readiness and collective commitment to the upcoming campaign.

The program focused on community mobilisation, enforcement collaboration, rehabilitation pathways, and the urgent need to protect young people from harmful drug abuse—especially Kush.
content:
CArCRT (formerly CADacT) and Partners Engage the Public Ahead of November 15th Drugs Campaign in Kenema

Ahead of the November 15th Drugs Campaign in Kenema, the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT), formerly CADacT, and its partners appeared on a simulcast radio discussion to speak on their readiness and collective commitment to the upcoming campaign.

The program focused on community mobilisation, enforcement collaboration, rehabilitation pathways, and the urgent need to protect young people from harmful drug abuse—especially Kush.

Guest Speakers

Saffa Andrew Koroma – CEO, CArCRT (formerly CADacT)

Bob Musa Mansaray – LUC, Kenema Police Division

Nancy A. Mustapha – Executive Director, Widows Empowerment Organization, Kenema

Jamie Brima – Widows Empowerment Organization, Kenema

Presenter

Hassan Sheriff

Host Radio

Kamboi Agriculture Radio

The broadcast served as a united call to action, emphasizing prevention, rehabilitation support, and strong community involvement in the fight against drug misuse in Sierra Leone.

title: Media Engagement: CArCRT-SL on Nyapui Radio – “Insai Salone” (16 Days of Activism Edition)
excerpt: As part of the ongoing 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence, the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation – Sierra Leone (CArCRT-SL) participated in today’s edition of the “Insai Salone” program on Nyapui Radio.
content:
Media Engagement: CArCRT-SL on Nyapui Radio – “Insai Salone” (16 Days of Activism Edition)

As part of the ongoing 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence, the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation – Sierra Leone (CArCRT-SL) participated in today’s edition of the “Insai Salone” program on Nyapui Radio.

The conversation focused on the organization’s continued efforts in drug abuse prevention, community resilience, gender justice, and youth protection, aligning with this year's global call to action to end all forms of violence and harm in communities.

Through this media engagement, CArCRT-SL reaffirmed its commitment to:

Raising awareness on the impact of substance abuse and gender-based violence

Empowering communities with information and prevention strategies

Advocating for safer, healthier, and more resilient communities

This appearance underscores the coalition’s dedication to amplifying voices, strengthening partnerships, and driving national action throughout the 16 Days of Activism campaign.

title: Day 13 – 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence
excerpt:
CArCRT-SL Engages Ansarul Islamic Secondary School, Kenema

On Day 13 of the global 16 Days of Activism, the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT-SL) conducted an impactful awareness session at Ansarul Islamic Secondary School, Kenema, focusing on the ongoing fight to end digital violence against women and girls.
content:
Day 13 – 16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence
CArCRT-SL Engages Ansarul Islamic Secondary School, Kenema

On Day 13 of the global 16 Days of Activism, the Coalition for Community Resilience and Transformation (CArCRT-SL) conducted an impactful awareness session at Ansarul Islamic Secondary School, Kenema, focusing on the ongoing fight to end digital violence against women and girls.

The engagement brought together students, teachers, and school administrators to discuss the growing risks of online harassment, cyberbullying, and harmful digital behaviors that disproportionately affect girls and young women.

During the session, the CArCRT-SL team encouraged both boys and girls to:

Promote responsible and respectful online behavior

Create and protect safe digital spaces

Challenge harmful stereotypes and digital abuse

Stand up for victims and report incidents of cyberviolence

The organization emphasized that everyone—regardless of gender or background—deserves safety, respect, and dignity online.

This activity is part of CArCRT-SL’s commitment to building resilient communities and empowering the next generation to champion a safer digital environment for all.
